summary: On May 17, 2017, the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York entered a judgment finding that Steven J. Huffman, a licensed pharmacist, was in contempt of the court for failing to pay spousal support.  According to the court's order, Huffman had been sanctioned for a past pharmacy violation in March, 2015.  The court found that Huffman was not in contempt for paying the support, and that he did not willfully violate the agreed judgment entry.  As alleged in the court order, the court found Huffman in contempt because he failed to pay the support and was unable to find work as a full-time pharmacist.  In a parallel action, on March 22, 2016, the federal district court for the Middle District of Pennsylvania issued a judgment ordering Huffman to pay a civil penalty of $7,542.00, the amount of support in arrearage from January 31, 2017 for Huffman's failure to pay, and imposing a 30-day jail sentence.  Without admitting or denying the allegations in the judgment, the defendant consented to the entry of a final judgment that permanently enjoins him from violating the charged provisions of the federal securities laws and orders him to pay $1,000.00 in restitution, a $250,000 civil penalty, and a $50,000 officer-and-director bar. The court also ordered Huffman not to violate the provision of Section 10(b) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 ("Exchange Act") and Rule 10b-5 thereunder, and to pay disgorgement of ill-gotten gains plus prejudgment interest of $2,038.00.  On May 24, 2018, the trial court issued its judgment in favor of Huffman finding him in contempt, ordering him to seek employment at 30 places per month and impose a 30–day term of jail if Huffman did not comply with the order. The judgment also imposed a $500,000 penalty against Huffman.  A hearing scheduled for June 27, 2017 was not scheduled for that day.  To learn more about contempt, see Litigation Release No. 17-cv-17-17 (January 22, 2017).  The SEC's complaint charges Huffman with violating the antifraud provisions of Sections 5(a), 5(c), and 17(a) of The Securities Act of 1933 ("Securities Act").  The complaint seeks permanent injunctions, civil penalties, and penny stock bars against him from participating in the issuance, purchase, offer, or sale of any security, including the right to reapply after five years of being barred from serving as an officer or director of a public company.
